Classifications: Jumping into the Sea for Fish
Variation Example: A numskull jumps into the sea (into a lake) to catch fish.

Numskulls throw a rabbit (crab, locust, sparrow) into boil-ing water in order to make soup. The animal escapes. Later the num-skulls drink the water & maintain that they have good soup. In some variants the “soup” is made from (1) the shadow of an animal (rooster, chicken) that falls on a kettle of water, (2) a rabbit that runs through a puddle (gets drowned in a river) or by ducks that swim on a pond, (3) water from washing hands (washing out bas kets) that were in contact with meat or fish.

Classifications: Numskull Strikes All Matches in Order to Try Them
Variation Example: A farmhand is sent to buy the best matches. To make sure that the matches will burn he lights them all to try them out.

The elabor-ate form of this type consists of several events: A rich man (ruler) promises a reward to anyone who can survive a cold night on the roof of the palace naked. A poor (foreign) man agrees to this proposal & survives the frosty night. In the morning the ruler refuses to give the poor man the reward, claiming that he had used a distant fire (the moonlight) to warm himself. On the advice of a wise man, the poor man invites the ruler to a meal. He puts the pot so far away from the fire that the food cannot cook. When his guests demand an explanation, he explains that the pot will be heated as he himself was warmed by the distant fire. The ruler pays the reward. This tale also exists in a short form: A numskull pretends to roast (believes he is roasting) meat: The fire burns on one shore of a lake, the meat is on the other.
In order to find out whether it is hot, a smith spits on a horseshoe. A fool who observed him spits into the porridge (soup) to test its temperature.

Classifications: The Porridge Eaten in Different Rooms
Variation Example: Fools sit together in a room & eat porridge. Every time they want a spoonful of milk (cream, honey) to eat with their porridge, they go into the room (cellar) where the milk is. A stranger tells them to put a jug of milk on the table.

Classifications: The Boiling of the Porridge Pot
Variation Example: Mistaking the sound of boiling, a woman who is cooking porridge thinks the pot is complaining to her a fool thinks the porridge is calling him).

Classifications: Two for the Price of One
Variation Example: A fool sells two fox skins rolled together for the price of one. In some variants a female knife-dealer tries to “cheat” her famous guest by selling a knife at half price.
A fool sells a third of a cask of grain for the price of a fourth. In some variants buyers boast of their “cleverness”: They payed a higher price than the seller asked.

This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: Numskulls want to elect a mayor. (1) The applicant who is able to make a short rhyme will be elected . All fail except the pigherd. (2) All candidates sit around a table & lay their beards on it. A louse is put into the middle. The man into whose beard the louse crawls will be elected. (3) The wives of the candidates have to undress & to put their heads into a haystack. Whoever is able to recognize his wife from her backside will become mayor. Various signals, either prearranged or accidental, affect the outcome. (In recent variants the parts are changed: The women have to recognize their husbands by their naked backsides.) (4) The winner of a footrace will become mayor. A calf crosses the finish line first, winning the race.
A numskull lays wet (recently manufactured) candles on (in) the stove to dry. They melt. In a Japanese version, numskulls mistake a candle for food & try to cook it. It melts.

An (old) foolish woman (maid) tries to warm her house with wool, which she burns in a stove. In some variants, the woman tries to warm the stove by putting a burning candle into it. In a Livonian version, yarn is tied around the stove so that the heat will not escape.

A foolgives a cloak to a stone in order to keep it warm. In some variants, a trembling tree is covered with cloth, a stump is covered with a cap, or stone Buddhas are protected by straw hats from snow & rain.
A numskull dries snow on a stove (water in the sun). In a Mexican version, a numskull carries ice cream in his pocket, where it melts. He thinks that he has been cheated.

A numskull comes to a stream & sits down to wait for the stream to run down so his feet will not get wet. Finally he tries to bail out the water out of the stream with a hazelnut shell, & keeps working for months. In a Cambodian version, a married couple wants to bail out the sea in order to get the treasures of sunken ships. Fish deliver gold & silver to the couple to make them stop bailing.

Numskulls turn their sledges (wagons, shoes) in the direction of their journey. At night a joker turns the sledges around. The numskulls do not notice the trick & drive (go) back home. They do not recognize their own town.
Numskull(s) lose(s) their (his) way & get(s) turned around. They find themselves back home. (They do not recognize themselves & ask their wives where their husbands are.)

Two women (men) row in opposite directions. They make no progress at all. (To solve the problem, they take out the plug at the bottom of the boat, so that one is obliged to baile out the water.) In some variants numskulls row a boat which is tied up.

Classifications: Prayer for a Change of Wind
Variation Example: An old woman walking (rowing) against the wind prays for it to change. The wind changes & she must walk against it on her return.

Classifications: Marking the place on the boat
Variation Example: An object falls into the sea from a boat. Numskull(s) mark(s) the place on the boatrail (place a sign on the water) to indicate where it fell. In some variants, numskull(s) mark a good fishing spot by a sign on the bottom of their boat, seek the ears of grain in the direction of the cloud that marks where they had sowed the grain, or hide money in the ground, taking the moon (a cloud) overhead as a mark.

Classifications: Getting Rid of the Unknown Animal
Variation Example: People who have never seen a cat (owl) buy one to free them from a plague of mice. The cat eats many mice & the people are afraid that it might eat them, too. So they decide to kill the cat but cannot catch it. They finally set the house on fire.

Classifications: Getting Rid of the Man-Eating Calf
Variation Example: A man who likes the shoes on the feet of a man hanging from the gallows, cuts off the swollen feet in order to carry off the shoes. In the room where he sleeps that night there is a newborn calf. The next morning the man takes the shoes but leaves the feet (he leaves the feet in the shoes). The people in the house think that the calf has eaten the man all but the feet. They kill the calf (burn the house to destroy the calf). In some variants, a cat (tom cat) is supposed to be a maneater.

Classifications: House Burned Down to Rid It of Insects
Variation Example: Fools burn down a house (tree) to rid it of insects (rats, crows, owl). In some variants, a garden (meadow) is paved to keep out moles.

While a foolish man (farmer, numskulls) sleeps, someone modifies his appearance (puts a cap on his head, cuts his beard or hair off, dresses him in new clothes, takes away a significant object, etc.). When the fool wakes up, he does not know himself or mistakes himself for someone else.
Forcing the Hen to brood her chickens. A foolish woman forces a hen to keep her chicks underneath her so that it is not possible for the hawk to steal them.

Classifications: White Man Made to Beleive He is Black
Variation Example: A white man who wants to stay in an inn overnight has to share his bed with a black man. While the white guest is sleeping, the host blackens his face. When the white man gets up in the morning & sees his dark face in a mirror, he thinks that the host has awakened the black man instead of him.

Classifications: Man Needs Patch on Pants to Recognize Himself
Variation Example: A man (fool) recognizes himself by some peculiar sign (patch on his trousers, ribbon around his hand or foot, flask on his belt, etc). Without this sign, he cannot tell himself from other people (he becomes confused when he meets someone else with the same sign).

A fool meets two people & asks one of them, “Are you you or your brother?”. In other versions the fool asks which is the man & which is the woman. Or he meets a man & asks him, “Was it you who died recently, or your brother?”
A foolish woman has sewn a shirt for her husband (son) without a hole for the head. She tries to beat the shirt over the man’s head, or she cuts his head off so that the shirt can be put on him.

A fool does not know how to pull on his breeches. He jumps down from a high place (e.g. rafters, tree) while his wife (another fool) keeps the breeches open (the breeches are hung up from hooks). (A stranger explains how to pull on the breeches & usually is rewarded.) In some variants, a child wears trousers with one leg (baby is wrapped in one piece of cloth). Therefore it cannot stand & seems to be crippled.

Classifications: Numskull unable to count their own number
Variation Example: Numskulls go swimming & then want to find out if everyone is back. The fools cannot get the right result because whoever counts forgets to count himself. They conclude that one of them is drowned. A stranger who finds the numskulls in distress tells them to stick their noses in the sand (loam) & to count the holes. So they confirm that everyone is still alive.

Classifications: Numskiulls Cannot Find Their Own Legs
Variation Example: Numskulls (wearing trousers or stockings of the same color, being drunk) fall down in a crowd (sit side by side swinging their legs). When they want to stand up they cannot find their own legs. A stranger helps the numskulls by whipping (striking) their legs. In some variants, a fool’s boots are stolen while he is drunk. He does not recognize his feet without boots.
A man runs in the dark holding his arms stretched out in front of him. He hits his nose on a ladder (the edge of an open door). He is surprised that his nose seems to be longer than his arms.

Classifications: Numskull Cannot Find the Donkey He is Sitting On
Variation Example: A numskull counting his donkeys (horses, camels) forgets to count the one he is sitting on. When he dismounts he always has one donkey more than when he sits on one of the animals. (He decides to walk rather than to lose one donkey.)
A fool thanks God that he was not sitting on the donkey when it was stolen.

Classifications: Each Wants to Sleep in the Middle
Variation Example: Each of three (two) numskulls wants to sleep in the middle. They do not know how to manage this & finally lie down head to head (feet to feet).
Numskulls (a foolish man or woman) mistake a waving blue field of flax for the sea (a lake, river). They take off their clothes & jump in for a swim.

A numskull who has slept on a feather (piece of straw) during the night finds himself completely sore & stiff in the morning. He wonders how anyone could stand to sleep on a featherbed (straw mattress).

Classifications: One Cheese Sent to Bring Back Another
Variation Example: A foolish woman loses a cheese which falls & rolls down a hill. She sends a second cheese (the other ones) to bring back the first.

Classifications: Three-legged Pot Sent to Walk Home
Variation Example: Numskulls buy a three-legged pot (spinning wheel, tripod) at the market. They try to send it home reasoning that, since it has three legs, it can walk home more easily & quickly than a two-legged man. In some variants, a four-legged table is sent home.
